bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, 1720 July 13

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant William Dawkins, July 13, 1720, to chide him "That those Gent. who do my business in England must Expect to undergo the Trouble of my extra Services," and that Carter's business alone is payment for those services, which in this instance involved business with "Bassnett & Millcraven from Jamaica" which Carter expects Dawkins to straighten out for him.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Dawkins, July 13, 1720

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
July 13th. 1720.
Mr Wm. Dawkins
Sir—

div1.p:
I am now upon Yor. Letter relating to the Jama
=ica Affair & give You my Thanks for the Trouble You have bin
at, but You must give me leave to observe to You, That those
Gent. who do my business in England must Expect to undergo
the Trouble of my extra Services, and that wth. out the opinion of
Abundance of merrit, any farther than the value of my
business, and You are mightily in the wrong to believe any
person makes any profitt from me upon such Accots.

I find You have pd. them the ball[an] ce & the produce
of the last Tobo., So that I have done wth. that Accot. in Every
respect, Mitchell hath had the Accot. of Sales & Accot.
Currt. Through Yor. hands and Yett Bassnett & Millcraven
from Jamaica write to me for the Accots. of that
Vessels Cargo a Coppy of The Lettr. I herewth. Send You
As also a Coppy of Bassnetts Lettr. from London the
30th of Novr. last requesting You will press Mitchell
to give those Gentns. Sattisfaction, for I take myself to
be no further Concern'd abt. It & besides It is very rare that
any opportunity happens from hence Directly to Jamaica
Especially from the parts where I live—

You mention the Sending me a Coppy of the Accot.
of Sales of their last four hogsheads but I have It not pray
remember to lett It be sent to me I am

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . pp. 13-14.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
